awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: A Teleconnection between the Tropical Madden-Julian Oscillation and Arctic Sudden Stratospheric Warming Events in Warm Climates
awd_abstract_narration:
The wintertime winds of the Northern Hemisphere stratosphere form a vortex circulating around a cold low pressure cell over the Arctic. Occasionally, perhaps six time in a decade, the vortex experiences a major disruption known as a stratospheric sudden warming (SSW), in which the Arctic stratosphere warms by tens of degrees celsius in just a few days.  SSWs are often followed by cold air outbreaks and other forms of severe weather, thus they are of practical as well as scientific interest. 

Classical studies of SSWs established that the breakdown of the vortex is caused by planetary-scale waves propagating upward and northward into the polar stratosphere.  These waves can originate in various ways, and previous work by the PIs and others finds that some SSWs can be linked to the tropical Madden-Julian Oscillation (MJO).  The MJO is a broad envelope of cloudiness and convective rainfall that forms over the equatorial Indian Ocean and propagates slowly eastward as far as the central Pacific.  Planetary waves generated by the MJO are known to affect weather in middle and high latitudes but their effect on SSWs has not received much attention until recently. The MJO-SSW connection is of particular interest given recent studies suggesting that MJO activity increases when tropical sea surface temperatures (SSTs) increase. The increase in MJO activity suggests greater SSW frequency, but other factors such as changes in the jet streams in a warming climate must also be considered.

This project examines the MJO-SSW connection in a hierarchy of models of varying degrees of complexity. The research is enabled by a specialized model configuration which is capable of simulating both the MJO, which is notoriously difficult to capture in current weather and climate models, and SSWs.  The model uses superparameterization (SP), a technique pioneered by one of the PIs in which cloud resolving models are embedded in every grid column of a global model (see AGS-0425247).  The SP technique is applied in the Community Atmosphere Model (CAM, the atmospheric component model of the Community Earth System Model), used here with enhanced vertical resolution to capture stratospheric dynamics. 

The work has broader impacts due to the effects of SSWs on surface weather in the Northern Hemisphere. The warming of tropical SSTs raises the prospect of stronger MJO events, and it is of practical interest to understand how stronger events will affect weather regimes over the US and other countries.  Moreover, the slow propagation of the MJO offers some hope for extended-range prediction of extreme weather linked to SSWs, thus research on the MJO-SSW connection has implications for operational weather forecasting.  The project has educational broader impacts through summer internships supporting undergraduates and local high school students, who are trained in python programming and atmospheric data analysis. The award also provides support and training to two graduate students, thereby providing for the future workforce in this research area.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project dealt with connections between climate variability modes that occur in the stratosphere — the upper part of the atmosphere between about 15–50 km height above the surface — and the troposphere, in the lower 10–15 km. We addressed connections between two climate variability modes in the stratosphere and one in the troposphere, in both the present and warmer climates.

The three modes are, first the Madden-Julian oscillation (MJO) in the tropical troposphere, which is composed of large-scale clusters of eastward-propagating clouds in the tropics of the Indian Ocean and the western Pacific Ocean. The MJO has a zonal scale of thousands of kilometers and a typical period of 40 days. It affects weather over the continents all around the Pacific basin and beyond. The first stratospheric mode is the quasi-biennial oscillation (QBO) which involves easterly and westerly winds in the stratosphere that alternate in time, with a period of about 28 months. The second stratospheric mode is sudden stratospheric warming events (SSWs), which occur in the present climate about 6 times per decade. SSWs involve a collapse of the northern polar stratospheric vortex, corresponding warming of some 40 °C in the stratosphere, and extreme cold events at the surface over North America and Europe.

Our project had two main threads dealing with the above three variability modes. First, we suggested and examined a hypothesis that the recently observed connection between the stratospheric QBO and the strength of the MJO is modulated by the sea-surface temperature (SST), and specifically by El Niño and the Southern Oscillation (ENSO). We found a remarkable similarity between the observed global SST composites (i.e., averages) for the easterly phase of the QBO and La Niña. A composite analysis shows that Nino3.4 SSTs are synchronized with the QBO. A Maximum Covariance (correlation) Analysis shows a connection between MJO power and SST, suggesting that the SST may play a role in coupling the QBO and the MJO. We analyzed a simulation with version 2 of the Community Earth System coupled ocean-atmosphere Model, with a higher top that includes the stratosphere and increased vertical resolution that allows a more realistic stratospheric simulation. The model produces a good representation of the QBO, ENSO, and the MJO, but it fails to reproduce the observed MJO signal when given prescribed SSTs that are based on observations. Our results regarding the role of SST are thus inconclusive, but they suggest that the SST plays a role, and specifically that ENSO may modulate both the QBO and the MJO, leading to a correlation between the QBO and the intensity of the MJO. Models that can better reproduce the covariance of the QBO and the MJO are needed to further test this hypothesis.

In the second thread of our work on stratospheric-tropospheric climate variability connections, we studied the recent suggestion that the frequency of SSWs may significantly increase in a global-warming scenario due to an expected strengthening of the MJO. This increase is proposed to be driven by atmospheric waves emitted by the stronger MJO in the tropics, which propagate to the polar stratosphere. We attempted to enhance the understanding of the MJO-SSW teleconnection in both the present and warmer climates and to provide a quantitative prediction of the effects of the expected MJO strengthening in a warmer climate on SSW events. The MJO is notoriously difficult to simulate using standard atmospheric models, yet is well-represented in “super-parameterized” models that represent moist convection and cloud processes using a high-resolution two-dimensional cloud model embedded in each grid of the coarser-resolution three-dimensional global atmospheric model. We developed the first super-parameterized atmospheric model that extends into the stratosphere and can successfully simulate both the MJO and SSW events. We used the model to study the possible enhancement in SSW frequency in a business-as-usual (RCP8.5/SSP5 8.5) climate warming scenario.
